up.translation[0].definitions[0].definit: towards a higher place or position
up.translation[0].definitions[0].example: We walked slowly up the hill.
She picked her jacket up off the floor.
paths leading up into the mountains
Tim had climbed up a tree to get a better view.
Put up your hand if you know the answer.
The water was getting up my nose.
Karen lay on her back, staring up at the ceiling.
up.translation[0].definitions[1].definit: in a higher place or position
up.translation[0].definitions[1].example: Her office is just up those stairs.
The doctor’s assistant was up a ladder in the stockroom.
up.translation[0].definitions[2].definit: into an upright or raised position
up.translation[0].definitions[2].example: Everyone stood up for the national anthem.
Mick turned his collar up against the biting winds.
up.translation[0].definitions[3].definit: in or to a place that is further along something such as a road or path
up.translation[0].definitions[3].example: She lives just up the street.
We walked up the road towards the church.
up.translation[0].definitions[4].example: We’re driving up to Chicago for the conference.
a stormy voyage up the east coast from Miami to Boston
up.translation[0].definitions[5].definit: very close to someone or something
up.translation[0].definitions[5].example: A man came up and offered to buy him a drink.
She drove right up to the front door.
The bed was up against the wall.
up.translation[0].definitions[6].definit: used to show that the place someone goes to is more important than the place they start from
up.translation[0].definitions[6].example: Have you been up to London recently?
up.translation[0].definitions[7].definit: towards the place where a river starts
up.translation[0].definitions[7].example: The river steamers only went up as far as Mandalay.
up.translation[0].definitions[8].definit: at or towards a higher level or a greater amount
up.translation[0].definitions[8].example: Violent crime went up by 9% last year.
Profits are up on last year.
up.translation[0].definitions[8].note_bo: In written English, people often prefer to use rise rather than be/go up, because it sounds more formal:
Violent crime rose by 9% last year.
up.translation[0].definitions[9].definit: beating your opponent by a certain number of points
up.translation[0].definitions[9].example: United were a goal up at half time.
two goals up/three points up etc
up.translation[0].definitions[10].exampl: They stayed up all night to watch the game.
It’s time to get up (=get out of bed).
It’s good to see you up and about again  (=out of bed after an illness and moving around normally).
up.translation[0].definitions[11].defini: used after certain verbs to show that something is completely finished, used, or removed
up.translation[0].definitions[11].exampl: We’ve used up all our savings.
The children had to eat up all their food.
After a month, the wound had almost healed up.
up.translation[0].definitions[12].defini: used after certain verbs to show that something is cut, broken etc into pieces or divided into parts
up.translation[0].definitions[12].exampl: Why did you tear up that letter?
We still haven’t decided how to divide up the money.
up.translation[0].definitions[13].defini: used after certain verbs to show that things are collected together
up.translation[0].definitions[13].exampl: Let’s just add up these figures quickly.
Could you collect up the papers?
up.translation[0].definitions[14].defini: used to say which surface or part of an object should be on top
up.translation[0].definitions[14].exampl: Put the playing cards right side up.
Isn’t that painting the wrong way up?
up.translation[0].definitions[15].defini: above and including a certain level, age, or amount
up.translation[0].definitions[15].exampl: All the women were naked from the waist up.
Children aged 12 and up must pay the full fare.
up.translation[0].definitions[16].defini: if a period of time is up, it is finished
up.translation[0].definitions[16].exampl: I’m sorry, we’ll have to stop there. Our time is up.
up.translation[0].definitions[17].defini: if a road is up, its surface is being repaired
up.translation[0].definitions[18].defini: if a computer system is up, it is working
up.translation[0].definitions[18].exampl: There could well be a few problems before your new computer is up and running properly.
up.translation[2].definitions[0].definit: to increase the amount or level of something
up.translation[3].definitions[0].example: to upgrade a job  (=make it higher in importance)
up.translation[3].definitions[1].definit: at or towards the top or beginning of something
up.translation[3].definitions[1].example: upriver  (=nearer to where the river starts)
up.translation[3].definitions[2].definit: taking something from its place or turning it upside down
up.translation[3].definitions[3].definit: at or towards the higher or better part of something
up.translation[4].definitions[0].definit: if a computer, machine etc is up, it is working normally and not broken
